segment.source: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to a resource, with additional system logic that retrieves different resources depending on the currently active theme.
segment.target: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to a resource, with additional system logic that retrieves different resources depending on the currently active theme.

segment.source: {ThemeResource} markup extension
segment.target: {ThemeResource} markup extension

segment.source: {ThemeResource} markup extension
segment.target: {ThemeResource} markup extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to a resource, with additional system logic that retrieves different resources depending on the currently active theme.
segment.target: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to a resource, with additional system logic that retrieves different resources depending on the currently active theme.

segment.source: Similar to {StaticResource} markup extension, resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a ThemeResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: Similar to {StaticResource} markup extension, resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a ThemeResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: key
segment.target: key

segment.source: The key for the requested resource.
segment.target: The key for the requested resource.

segment.source: This key is initially assigned by the ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: This key is initially assigned by the ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: A resource key can be any string defined in the XamlName Grammar.
segment.target: A resource key can be any string defined in the XamlName Grammar.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: A ThemeResource is a technique for obtaining values for a XAML attribute that are defined elsewhere in a XAML resource dictionary.
segment.target: A ThemeResource is a technique for obtaining values for a XAML attribute that are defined elsewhere in a XAML resource dictionary.

segment.source: The markup extension serves the same basic purpose as the {StaticResource} markup extension.
segment.target: The markup extension serves the same basic purpose as the {StaticResource} markup extension.

segment.source: The difference in behavior versus {StaticResource} markup extension is that a ThemeResource reference can dynamically use different dictionaries as the primary lookup location, depending on which theme is currently being used by the system.
segment.target: The difference in behavior versus {StaticResource} markup extension is that a ThemeResource reference can dynamically use different dictionaries as the primary lookup location, depending on which theme is currently being used by the system.

segment.source: When the app first starts, any resource reference made by a ThemeResource reference is evaluated based on the theme in use at startup.
segment.target: When the app first starts, any resource reference made by a ThemeResource reference is evaluated based on the theme in use at startup.

segment.source: But if the user subsequently changes the active theme at run-time, the system will re-evaluate every ThemeResource reference, retrieve a theme-specific resource that may be different, and redisplay the app with new resource values in all appropriate places in the visual tree.
segment.target: But if the user subsequently changes the active theme at run-time, the system will re-evaluate every ThemeResource reference, retrieve a theme-specific resource that may be different, and redisplay the app with new resource values in all appropriate places in the visual tree.

segment.source: A StaticResource is determined at XAML load time / app startup and won't be re-evaluated at run-time.
segment.target: A StaticResource is determined at XAML load time / app startup and won't be re-evaluated at run-time.

segment.source: (There are other techniques such as visual states that reload XAML dynamically, but those techniques operate at a higher level that the basic resource evaluation enabled by {StaticResource} markup extension).
segment.target: (There are other techniques such as visual states that reload XAML dynamically, but those techniques operate at a higher level that the basic resource evaluation enabled by {StaticResource} markup extension).

segment.source: ThemeResource takes one argument, which specifies the key for the requested resource.
segment.target: ThemeResource takes one argument, which specifies the key for the requested resource.

segment.source: A resource key is always a string in Windows Runtime XAML.
segment.target: A resource key is always a string in Windows Runtime XAML.

segment.source: For more info on how the resource key is initially specified, see x:Key attribute.
segment.target: For more info on how the resource key is initially specified, see x:Key attribute.

segment.source: For more info on how to define resources and properly use a ResourceDictionary, including sample code, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: For more info on how to define resources and properly use a ResourceDictionary, including sample code, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: As with StaticResource, a ThemeResource must not attempt to make a forward reference to a resource that is defined lexically further within the XAML file.
segment.target: As with StaticResource, a ThemeResource must not attempt to make a forward reference to a resource that is defined lexically further within the XAML file.

segment.source: Attempting to do so is not supported.
segment.target: Attempting to do so is not supported.

segment.source: Even if the forward reference doesn't fail, trying to make one carries a performance penalty.
segment.target: Even if the forward reference doesn't fail, trying to make one carries a performance penalty.

segment.source: For best results, adjust the composition of your resource dictionaries so that forward references are avoided.
segment.target: For best results, adjust the composition of your resource dictionaries so that forward references are avoided.

segment.source: Attempting to specify a ThemeResource to a key that cannot resolve throws a XAML parse exception at run time.
segment.target: Attempting to specify a ThemeResource to a key that cannot resolve throws a XAML parse exception at run time.

segment.source: Design tools may also offer warnings or errors.
segment.target: Design tools may also offer warnings or errors.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for ThemeResource.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for ThemeResource.

segment.source: The closest equivalent in code is to use the collection API of a ResourceDictionary, for example calling Contains or TryGetValue.
segment.target: The closest equivalent in code is to use the collection API of a ResourceDictionary, for example calling Contains or TryGetValue.

segment.source: ThemeResource is a markup extension.
segment.target: ThemeResource is a markup extension.

segment.source: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.
segment.target: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.

segment.source: All markup extensions in XAML use the "{" and "}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.
segment.target: All markup extensions in XAML use the "{" and "}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.

segment.source: When and how to use {ThemeResource} rather than {StaticResource}
segment.target: When and how to use {ThemeResource} rather than {StaticResource}

segment.source: The rules by which a ThemeResource resolves to an item in a resource dictionary are generally the same as StaticResource.
segment.target: The rules by which a ThemeResource resolves to an item in a resource dictionary are generally the same as StaticResource.

segment.source: A ThemeResource lookup can extend into the ResourceDictionary files that are referenced in a ThemeDictionaries collection, but a StaticResource can do that also.
segment.target: A ThemeResource lookup can extend into the ResourceDictionary files that are referenced in a ThemeDictionaries collection, but a StaticResource can do that also.

segment.source: The difference is that a ThemeResource can re-evaluate at run-time and a StaticResource can't.
segment.target: The difference is that a ThemeResource can re-evaluate at run-time and a StaticResource can't.

segment.source: The set of keys in each theme dictionary should provide the same set of keyed resources no matter which theme is active.
segment.target: The set of keys in each theme dictionary should provide the same set of keyed resources no matter which theme is active.

segment.source: If a given keyed resource exists in the HighContrast theme dictionary, then another resource with that name should also exist in Light and Default.
segment.target: If a given keyed resource exists in the HighContrast theme dictionary, then another resource with that name should also exist in Light and Default.

segment.source: If that isn't true, resource lookup might fail when the user switches themes and your app won't look right.
segment.target: If that isn't true, resource lookup might fail when the user switches themes and your app won't look right.

segment.source: It is possible though that a theme dictionary can contain keyed resources that are only referenced from within the same scope to provide sub-values; these don't need to be equivalent in all themes.
segment.target: It is possible though that a theme dictionary can contain keyed resources that are only referenced from within the same scope to provide sub-values; these don't need to be equivalent in all themes.

segment.source: In general you should place resources in theme dictionaries and make references to those resources using ThemeResource only when those values can change between themes or are supported by values that change.
segment.target: In general you should place resources in theme dictionaries and make references to those resources using ThemeResource only when those values can change between themes or are supported by values that change.

segment.source: This is appropriate for these kinds of resources:
segment.target: This is appropriate for these kinds of resources:

segment.source: Brushes, in particular colors for SolidColorBrush.
segment.target: Brushes, in particular colors for SolidColorBrush.

segment.source: These make up about 80% of the ThemeResource usages in the default XAML control templates (generic.xaml).
segment.target: These make up about 80% of the ThemeResource usages in the default XAML control templates (generic.xaml).

segment.source: Pixel values for borders, offsets, margin and padding and so on.
segment.target: Pixel values for borders, offsets, margin and padding and so on.

segment.source: Font properties such as FontFamily or FontSize.
segment.target: Font properties such as FontFamily or FontSize.

segment.source: Complete templates for a limited number of controls that are usually system-styled and used for dynamic presentation, like GridViewItem and ListViewItem.
segment.target: Complete templates for a limited number of controls that are usually system-styled and used for dynamic presentation, like GridViewItem and ListViewItem.

segment.source: Text display styles (usually to change font color, background, and possibly size).
segment.target: Text display styles (usually to change font color, background, and possibly size).

segment.source: The Windows Runtime provides a set of resources that are specifically intended to be referenced by ThemeResource.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime provides a set of resources that are specifically intended to be referenced by ThemeResource.

segment.source: These are all listed as part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml, which is available in the include/winrt/xaml/design folder as part of the Windows Software Development Kit (SDK).
segment.target: These are all listed as part of the XAML file themeresources.xaml, which is available in the include/winrt/xaml/design folder as part of the Windows Software Development Kit (SDK).

segment.source: For documentation on the theme brushes and additional styles that are defined in themeresources.xaml, see XAML theme resources.
segment.target: For documentation on the theme brushes and additional styles that are defined in themeresources.xaml, see XAML theme resources.

segment.source: The brushes are documented in a table that tells you what color value each brush has for each of the three possible active themes.
segment.target: The brushes are documented in a table that tells you what color value each brush has for each of the three possible active themes.

segment.source: The XAML definitions of visual states in a control template should use ThemeResource references whenever there's an underlying resource that might change because of a theme change.
segment.target: The XAML definitions of visual states in a control template should use ThemeResource references whenever there's an underlying resource that might change because of a theme change.

segment.source: A system theme change won't typically also cause a visual state change.
segment.target: A system theme change won't typically also cause a visual state change.

segment.source: The resources need to use ThemeResource references in this case so that values can be re-evaluated for the still-active visual state.
segment.target: The resources need to use ThemeResource references in this case so that values can be re-evaluated for the still-active visual state.

segment.source: For example, if you have a visual state that changes a brush color of a particular UI part and one of its properties, and that brush color is different per-theme, you should use a ThemeResource reference for providing that property's value in the default template and also any visual state modification to that default template.
segment.target: For example, if you have a visual state that changes a brush color of a particular UI part and one of its properties, and that brush color is different per-theme, you should use a ThemeResource reference for providing that property's value in the default template and also any visual state modification to that default template.

segment.source: ThemeResource usages might be seen in a series of dependent values.
segment.target: ThemeResource usages might be seen in a series of dependent values.

segment.source: For example, a Color value used by a SolidColorBrush that is also a keyed resource might use a ThemeResource reference.
segment.target: For example, a Color value used by a SolidColorBrush that is also a keyed resource might use a ThemeResource reference.

segment.source: But any UI properties that use the keyed SolidColorBrush resource would also use a ThemeResource reference, so that it's specifically each Brush-type property that's enabling a dynamic value change when the theme changes.
segment.target: But any UI properties that use the keyed SolidColorBrush resource would also use a ThemeResource reference, so that it's specifically each Brush-type property that's enabling a dynamic value change when the theme changes.

segment.source: Note and run-time resource evaluation on theme switching is supported in Windows 8.1 XAML but not supported in XAML for apps targeting Windows 8.
segment.target: Note and run-time resource evaluation on theme switching is supported in Windows 8.1 XAML but not supported in XAML for apps targeting Windows 8.

segment.source: System resources
segment.target: System resources

segment.source: Some theme resources reference system resource values as an underlying sub-value.
segment.target: Some theme resources reference system resource values as an underlying sub-value.

segment.source: A system resource is a special resource value that isn't found in any XAML resource dictionary.
segment.target: A system resource is a special resource value that isn't found in any XAML resource dictionary.

segment.source: These values rely on behavior in Windows Runtime XAML support to forward values from the system itself, and represent them in a form that a XAML resource can reference.
segment.target: These values rely on behavior in Windows Runtime XAML support to forward values from the system itself, and represent them in a form that a XAML resource can reference.

segment.source: For example, there is a system resource named "SystemColorButtonFaceColor" that represents an RGB color.
segment.target: For example, there is a system resource named "SystemColorButtonFaceColor" that represents an RGB color.

segment.source: This color comes from the aspects of system colors and themes that aren't just specific to Windows Runtime and Windows Runtime apps.
segment.target: This color comes from the aspects of system colors and themes that aren't just specific to Windows Runtime and Windows Runtime apps.

segment.source: System resources are often the underlying values for a high-contrast theme.
segment.target: System resources are often the underlying values for a high-contrast theme.

segment.source: The user is in control of the color choices for their high-contrast theme, and the user makes these choices using system features that also aren't specific to Windows Runtime apps.
segment.target: The user is in control of the color choices for their high-contrast theme, and the user makes these choices using system features that also aren't specific to Windows Runtime apps.

segment.source: By referencing the system resources as ThemeResource references, the default behavior of the high-contrast themes for Windows Runtime apps can use these theme-specific values that are controlled by the user and exposed by the system.
segment.target: By referencing the system resources as ThemeResource references, the default behavior of the high-contrast themes for Windows Runtime apps can use these theme-specific values that are controlled by the user and exposed by the system.

segment.source: Also, the references are now marked for re-evaluation if the system detects a run-time theme change.
segment.target: Also, the references are now marked for re-evaluation if the system detects a run-time theme change.

segment.source: An example {ThemeResource} usage
segment.target: An example {ThemeResource} usage

segment.source: Here's some example XAML taken from the default generic.xaml and themeresources.xaml files to illustrate how to use ThemeResource.
segment.target: Here's some example XAML taken from the default generic.xaml and themeresources.xaml files to illustrate how to use ThemeResource.

segment.source: We'll look at just one template (the default Button) and how two properties are declared (Background and Foreground) to be responsive to theme changes.
segment.target: We'll look at just one template (the default Button) and how two properties are declared (Background and Foreground) to be responsive to theme changes.

segment.source: Here, the properties take a Brush value, and the reference to SolidColorBrush resources named and are made using ThemeResource.
segment.target: Here, the properties take a Brush value, and the reference to SolidColorBrush resources named and are made using ThemeResource.

segment.source: These same properties are also adjusted by some of the visual states for a Button.
segment.target: These same properties are also adjusted by some of the visual states for a Button.

segment.source: Notably, the background color changes when a button is clicked.
segment.target: Notably, the background color changes when a button is clicked.

segment.source: Here too, the Background and Foreground animations in the visual state storyboard use DiscreteObjectKeyFrame objects and references to brushes with ThemeResource as the key frame value.
segment.target: Here too, the Background and Foreground animations in the visual state storyboard use DiscreteObjectKeyFrame objects and references to brushes with ThemeResource as the key frame value.

segment.source: Each of these brushes is defined earlier in generic.xaml: they had to be defined prior to any templates using them to avoid XAML forward references.
segment.target: Each of these brushes is defined earlier in generic.xaml: they had to be defined prior to any templates using them to avoid XAML forward references.

segment.source: Here's those definitions, for the "Default" theme dictionary.
segment.target: Here's those definitions, for the "Default" theme dictionary.

segment.source: Then each of the other theme dictionaries also has these brushes defined, for example:
segment.target: Then each of the other theme dictionaries also has these brushes defined, for example:

segment.source: Here the Color value is another ThemeResource reference to a system resource.
segment.target: Here the Color value is another ThemeResource reference to a system resource.

segment.source: If you reference a system resource, and you want it to change in response to a theme change, you should use ThemeResource to make the reference.
segment.target: If you reference a system resource, and you want it to change in response to a theme change, you should use ThemeResource to make the reference.

segment.source: Windows 8 behavior
segment.target: Windows 8 behavior

segment.source: Windows 8 did not support the ThemeResource markup extension, it is available starting with Windows 8.1.
segment.target: Windows 8 did not support the ThemeResource markup extension, it is available starting with Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Also, Windows 8 did not support dynamically switching the theme-related resources for a Windows Runtime app.
segment.target: Also, Windows 8 did not support dynamically switching the theme-related resources for a Windows Runtime app.

segment.source: The app had to be restarted in order to pick up the theme change for the XAML templates and styles.
segment.target: The app had to be restarted in order to pick up the theme change for the XAML templates and styles.

segment.source: This isn't a good user experience, so apps are strongly encouraged to recompile and target Windows 8.1 so that they can use styles with ThemeResource usages and can dynamically switch themes when the user does.
segment.target: This isn't a good user experience, so apps are strongly encouraged to recompile and target Windows 8.1 so that they can use styles with ThemeResource usages and can dynamically switch themes when the user does.

segment.source: Apps that were compiled for Windows 8 but running on Windows 8.1 continue to use the Windows 8 behavior.
segment.target: Apps that were compiled for Windows 8 but running on Windows 8.1 continue to use the Windows 8 behavior.

segment.source: Design-time tools support for the {ThemeResource} markup extension
segment.target: Design-time tools support for the {ThemeResource} markup extension

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 can include possible key values in the Microsoft IntelliSense dropdowns when you use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in a XAML page.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 can include possible key values in the Microsoft IntelliSense dropdowns when you use the {ThemeResource} markup extension in a XAML page.

segment.source: For example, as soon as you type "{ThemeResource", any of the resource keys from the XAML theme resources are displayed.
segment.target: For example, as soon as you type "{ThemeResource", any of the resource keys from the XAML theme resources are displayed.

segment.source: Once a resource key exists as part of any {ThemeResource} usage, the Go To Definition (F12) feature can resolve that resource and show you the generic.xaml for design time, where the theme resource is defined.
segment.target: Once a resource key exists as part of any {ThemeResource} usage, the Go To Definition (F12) feature can resolve that resource and show you the generic.xaml for design time, where the theme resource is defined.

segment.source: Because theme resources are defined more than once (per-theme) Go To Definition takes you to the first definition found in the file, which is the definition for Default.
segment.target: Because theme resources are defined more than once (per-theme) Go To Definition takes you to the first definition found in the file, which is the definition for Default.

segment.source: If you want the other definitions you can search for the key name within the file and find the other themes' definitions.
segment.target: If you want the other definitions you can search for the key name within the file and find the other themes' definitions.

segment.target: Related topics
